Some tips on communicating effectively with a diverse workforce include:

1. Be respectful and inclusive: Treat all employees with dignity and respect, regardless of their culture or background. This includes using appropriate language, avoiding offensive jokes or comments, and demonstrating genuine interest in people's lives outside of work.

2. Foster cultural awareness: Encourage employees to learn more about the cultures represented within your team. Offer training sessions on cross-cultural communication skills and actively promote understanding and appreciation for different backgrounds within your organization.

3. Practice active listening: Give everyone an equal opportunity to express their views by encouraging open discussion during meetings, brainstorming sessions, etc., while also being attentive listeners who ask thoughtful questions.

4. Use clear yet simple language: When communicating instructions or ideas—either verbally or in writing—use direct words that are not overly complex—even if you must break technical terms down into simpler explanations—to avoid misunderstandings caused by jargon-heavy discourse.

5. Utilize various communication channels: Some employees may prefer email; others might be more comfortable discussing matters face-to-face—but since some workers might find video conferencing preferable than physical interactions in this pandemic-stricken era (due to social distancing), experiment with multiple platforms until you identify which ones suitably accommodate everybody’s needs among those at hand.

6.Involve as many perspectives as possible when making decisions:
Allowing teams greater diversity exposes managers decision-making processes from multiple angles simultaneously; consequently providing invaluable input ultimately leading towards greater success likelihood over time.

7.Encourage teamwork across cultural boundaries.
